unnormalised: **Fuel Efficiency Still King for Indian Car Buyers**
normalised: **Fuel Efficiency Still King for Indian Car Buyers**

unnormalised: Bangalore, Oct 26 – Forget the fancy sunroofs and massive infotainment screens, folks. Fuel efficiency is still the *numero uno* consideration for most car buyers in India, especially with petrol prices hitting the roof!
normalised: Bangalore, October twenty sixth – Forget the fancy sunroofs and massive infotainment screens, folks. Fuel efficiency is still the numero uno consideration for most car buyers in India, especially with petrol prices hitting the roof!

unnormalised: A recent survey by the Automotive Research Association of India (ARAI) found that “mileage,” as we lovingly call it, trumps everything else for the average Sharmaji looking to upgrade his ride.
normalised: A recent survey by the A R A I found that “mileage,” as we lovingly call it, trumps everything else for the average Sharmaji looking to upgrade his ride.

unnormalised: Even with the rise of EVs, petrol and diesel cars are still the bread and butter, and stretching that litre of fuel is crucial. Think of it like making your Onam Sadhya stretch to feed the whole family – every little bit counts!
normalised: Even with the rise of E V S, petrol and diesel cars are still the bread and butter, and stretching that liter of fuel is crucial. Think of it like making your Onam Sadhya stretch to feed the whole family – every little bit counts!

unnormalised: Industry experts suggest that demand for fuel-efficient hatchbacks and compact sedans is surging ahead of Diwali.
normalised: Industry experts suggest that demand for fuel efficient hatchbacks and compact sedans is surging ahead of Diwali.

unnormalised: Maruti Suzuki and Hyundai continue to lead the pack, with models promising upwards of 25 kmpl. Looks like biryani and budget cars will continue to rule our hearts (and roads) for a while yet! And hey, who wouldn't want to save some Rupees on fuel, right? Happy driving, folks!
normalised: Maruti Suzuki and Hyundai continue to lead the pack, with models promising upwards of twenty five kilometer per liter. Looks like biryani and budget cars will continue to rule our hearts (and roads) for a while yet! And hey, who wouldn't want to save some Rupees on fuel, right? Happy driving, folks!
